name: NPR
text:
Texas reported more than 10,000 new coronavirus cases on Tuesday ‚Äî eclipsing its previous record for single-day increases, which the state set on Saturday.

name: NPR
text:
Federal regulators revoked a rule that requires payday lenders to check that borrowers can repay loans, which can carry interest rates as high as 400%. 

The new rule strips a key provision crafted during the Obama administration.
https://t.co/t7JVMqDh5q

name: NPR
text:

text:

text:

text: The Jayhawks' bandleader Gary Louris talks about the band‚Äôs songwriting process, plus his collaborations with other people, including the newly renamed trio The Chicks ‚Äî who you might know better as Dixie Chicks.  https://t.co/9oUFSFoKR7

text:

name: NPR
text:

"Can't be what you can't see,‚Äù photographer Sachi Cunningham says.

text:

‚ÄúIf we can say their names we can know more about their stories."

text:

name: NPR
text:
"We have an honor code: A cadet will not lie, cheat, steal or tolerate those who do," says Capt. Mary Tobin, a former West Point cadet. "We have an entire program devoted to that. ... That should also happen in regards to issues of racism."
https://t.co/Yq0Infe5Ay

name: NPR
text:

Global health experts say the move ‚Äúwill likely cost lives, American and foreign" to COVID-19.

name: NPR
text:
.@chelseahandler: "It's about the desire, you know, to learn more and to do better. And, you know, I think a lot of people are feeling that right now. And they understand privilege is something, and it's not deniable anymore."

name: NPR
text:
A nonprofit that investigates school funding inequities in America found that predominantly white school districts get collectively $23 billion more per year than predominantly nonwhite school districts.
https://t.co/rlcqZ25vwB

name: NPR
text:
Chief Justice John Roberts, 65, was hospitalized last month after falling and injuring his forehead.

He received sutures and was kept at the hospital overnight out of an abundance of caution, the Supreme Court says.
https://t.co/QtzexZJj7e

name: NPR
text:
A growing number of governors and mayors are making masks mandatory in public spaces to reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19.

But in some areas, local police and sheriffs are refusing to enforce the rules.
https://t.co/tcnKMaDBf6

name: NPR
text:

https://t.co/goKo77NMh5

name: NPR
text:
Presidents seeking a second term generally campaign on a unifying message, highlighting the work they've done and what they hope to accomplish for the American people.

Trump is choosing instead to reprise the most divisive themes of his 2016 campaign.
https://t.co/qbCfAp8paH

text:
